Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Working Lives and Spatial Practices of Digital Media Developers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will analyze the production of digital media and software and the spatial transformations and work practices and places to which they contribute. Its specific aim is to examine the systems of privilege - especially gendered privilege and exclusionary standards of masculinity - that influence the work practices and workplaces of digital media developers to shed critical light on the conditions leading to and perpetuating the exclusion of women software engineers from digital media firms. Specific research questions to be investigated include: How are everyday work practices conducted and structured in digital media work by its developers? What are the physical working spaces of digital media developers and how do they support or restrict particular work practices? In what ways are digital media developers' work practices and spaces gendered? Through a detailed study of the gendered spatial practices and dynamics of power in digital media workplaces in San Francisco, this research will contribute theoretical understanding to a range of scholarly disciplines including the sociology of work, new media, social media, geography, feminist theory, and STS. In terms of broader impacts, the findings of this research will inform and enhance efforts to expand participation in the STEM workforce by under-represented segments of the population.

The theoretical framework in which this research project is situated incorporates insights from cultural economic geography, feminist economic geography, and the sociology of work, which emphasize the importance of language, meaning, symbols, power, and subject identities and gendered and/or racialized performances in the economic sphere. The project draws on and contributes to research in these fields that point to the manner in which high tech and other high end service sector (e.g., finance) work presents particular workplace practices and performances of masculinity that are exclusionary. By analyzing precisely how gender bias constitutes a cultural component of economic practice that is normalized in everyday settings, the overarching objective of this study is to assess how positive change toward the broader inclusion of women and other under-represented groups in the digital media and software industry may be accomplished. Methods to be utilized include participant observation and semi-structured interviews with digital media developers in San Francisco, where several hundred digital media firms are located.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined the work practices of entrepreneurs and other workers in San Francisco’s early stage ‘startup’ firms, forming the research behind the PI’s doctoral dissertation. In this context ‘startups’ are distinguished from other firms by how they are financed. Startup firms seek equity - primarily through venture capital, but also other kinds of funds - rather than debt as a way to finance their operations. The focus of this study was on the effects of failure endemic to this kind of work – endemic because equity finance and venture capital is premised on short-term, high-risk investment in which the majority of investments (i.e., firms) are expected to fail. Failure in startup work is widely acknowledged, but often usually dismissed as merely an unfortunate side-effect, rather than discussed as an important structural factor of startup work. The methods employed to examine these phenomena were qualitative - primarily in-depth interviews with people working in these settings, and participant observation of networking and conferencing events with startup workers as the primarily audience. Qualitative methods have the benefit of showing how people relate to their work and to one another on an inter-personal and emotional level, building on recent writing in cultural and feminist economic geography that seeks to locate economic activity at the level of the individual and the workplace, in addition to at the level of markets and macro-economics. The main findings of this study are that working culture in San Francisco startup firms is characterized by high levels of pressure and stress at work that valorizes a volatile working life. Though perhaps suitable for those with existing degrees of wealth, privilege, social status, and personal financial safety nets, these precarious working conditions also affect workers in this setting who do not have these existing structures of support. In addition, San Francisco startup work, especially at the early stages of these firms can be characterized by discriminatory hiring and working practices that disadvantage women and people of color. Discrimination in this setting cannot be adequately explained through common excuses such as the so-called ‘pipeline problem’ (which is not to say that the lack of women graduating with STEM degrees is not a continuing, though distinct, problem) since women face systemic harassment and hostility in these working settings, and thus often leave these workplaces for ones that are less discriminatory. This research thus poses an important challenge to the accepted wisdom that marks ‘innovative economies’ as necessary social and economic good, and questions the cultures of work valorized therein. An open question moving forward with this research in other geographical settings, notably the City of London in the United Kingdom, and the Kitchener-Toronto corridor in Canada, is the extent to which these toxic working cultures are themselves mobile. This question is particularly relevant given the high-profile and highly-visible status of Silicon Valley and San Francisco as sites of supposed progressive social and technical innovation. If working conditions characterized by cultures of endemic failure and the negative implications therein are unduly glamorized, it is possible that said working conditions may have an impact upon work beyond the strictures of equity-investment and San Francisco startup work, forming a normative standard to be mimicked in other settings.
